page.title: 18Clarendon Estate Laverstock.
page.content: In recent years Clarendon Estate has developed Pheasant and Partridge breeding as part of its land use. There are two breeds of partidge, English and French also pheasant, in incubators and rearing pens. They are sited on the south facing slope of the valley below the ruins of Clarendon Palace, and opposite the 'jousting field' where some 700 years ago knights battled to gather the favours of the Ladies of the Royal Court, and no doubt where many other blood sports were held. Here some 8000 chicks each year are scrupulously reared before they are released into the surrounding trees and vegetation. The chicks are 'beak ringed' for a time to protect them from beak pecking habbits while they are young. Here they grow until the shooting season starts, when they pit their wits agaist the local shoot.
